rsbNotes.title: Ps 59
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 59 The psalm comes from the period before David became king. Saul set a watch over David’s house, hoping to kill him; but David’s wife Michal, the daughter of Saul, helped David escape (1 Sam. 19:11–17).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 59:3
rsbNotes.text: 59:3 For no transgression or sin of mine. The psalmist is not saying that he is without sin; he is asserting that the enemy has no cause against him. This was true of the original situation, where David had committed no aggression against Saul’s kingship. See Ps. 26.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 59:5
rsbNotes.text:
59:5 God of hosts. This divine title indicates that God has heavenly armies at His command.

nations . . . plot evil. The enemies come from the nations outside of Israel, but also from within.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 59:6
rsbNotes.text: 59:6 like dogs. The enemies are like a pack of dogs who roam the streets of the city and make them unsafe. Dogs were not valued in the ancient Near East.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 59:7
rsbNotes.text: 59:7 Who . . . will hear us. See 64:5 and note.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 59:10
rsbNotes.text:
59:10 God . . . will meet me. God will lead the way in the fight against the enemy. In the time of Joshua, the ark, symbolic of God’s presence, led Israel into the Promised Land.

look in triumph. For now, the enemy gloats over the psalmist, but the psalmist expects a reversal.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 59:11
rsbNotes.text: 59:11 Kill them not. The psalmist desires to prolong the suffering of the enemy. This will make them an example to the rest of Israel that evil doesn’t pay.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 59:12
rsbNotes.text: 59:12 sin of their mouths. Words are powerful, and can bring either great blessing or tremendous harm.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 59:13
rsbNotes.text: 59:13 that they may know. The ultimate goal of the destruction of the enemy is that the glory of God’s justice may be seen.
